wikipedia_page.main: Peter Felix Richards (1808–1868) was a pioneering Scottish merchant in post-Treaty of Nanjing Shanghai, and the founder of the Richards Hotel and Restaurant, the first foreign hotel in China, and the forerunner to the Astor House Hotel.

response: *Peter Felix Richards (1808–1868), pioneer Scottish merchant in post-Treaty of Nanjing Shanghai

Among the first foreign residents of Shanghai was Peter Felix Richards, a Scottish merchant. Richards had been doing business in China from about 1840;See P.F. Richards, 17 March 1861 from Tientsin, published in North-China Herald (6 April 1861). and in 1844 had established P.F. Richards & Co. (of Shanghai and Fuchowfoo).Mark Swislocki, Culinary Nostalgia: Regional Food Culture and the Urban Experience in Shanghai (Stanford University Press, 2008):104; Papers of miscellaneous companies, 1823–1940 (Manuscripts/MS JM/MS.JM/I28), Jardine Matheson Archive,  P.F. Richards operated a general store, a ship chandler, and a commissioned agent businessHibbard, Bund, 212; Shanghai Almanac and Miscellany (1856):111, where Richards is listed as "Ship Chandlers, General Store-keeper, Shipping Victuallers." on 4th Avenue (四马路) (now Fuzhou Road; 福州路). In 1846, Richards opened one of the first Western restaurants in ShanghaiMark Swislocki, Culinary Nostalgia: Regional Food Culture and the Urban Experience in Shanghai (Stanford University Press, 2008):107. and the first Western hotel in China.Note: Hibbard suggests that the Hotel was established in 1844. See Hibbard, Bund, 212. These were located south of the Yangkingpang (Yangjingbang) creek.Richards' Hotel and Restaurant (礼查饭店; "Licha"; Lee-zo).Teikoku Tetsudōchō, Japan, An Official Guide to Eastern Asia: Trans-Continental Connections between Europe and Asia Vol. 4 (Imperial Japanese Government Railways, 1915):233.

By 1851 Vacher had transferred to Shanghai, where from 9 August he was an authorised representative of Gilmam, Bowman, & Co.Haan. Vacher was a member of the Shanghai Municipal Council from 1852 to at least 1856, where he was a member of the Committee to study the erection of a new building for the Shanghai Library in 1852, and also a member of Committee II: Assessments of Foreign-owned property.J.H. Haan, "The Shanghai Municipal Council, 1850-1865: Some Biographical Notes", Journal of the Hong Kong Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society 24 (1984):207ff; http://sunzi1.lib.hku.hk/hkjo/view/44/4401556.pdf. In August 1855 Vacher was still resident in Shanghai.Shanghae Almanac for the Bissextile or Leap Year of 1856 and Miscellany, Vol. 5 (Printed at the "North-China Herald" Office., 1856). In May 1856 Vacher and Charles Wills (died in Shanghai in 1857) were assigned the assets of bankrupt British merchant Peter Felix Richards (died in China in 1868), which included the lugger-rigged vessel the Margaret Mitchell, and the Richards Hotel and Restaurant.
